title: How to Keep Pizzas Warm

methods.name: Warming the Pizza on the Ride Home

steps.headline: Put the box in an insulated bag or cooler.
steps.description: This is the best option for keeping your pizza warm! Slip the box into an insulated bag, much like the ones pizza delivery companies use to keep your pizza warm. You can also use a cooler, as long as it's wide enough to hold the pizza without placing it on its side. You could even slip a heating pad into the bag if you have one that will plug into your car.

steps.headline: Place the pizza on a heated seat.
steps.description: If your car comes equipped with this option, lucky you! Set the pizza box on the seat and turn the seat warmer on high. To help prevent heat loss, throw a clean blanket, towel, or even a jacket on top. This works best on cold days. Don't forget to turn the heater on, too. If you don't have heated seats, trying placing the pizza on the floor and turning the floor vents on high heat.

steps.headline: Set the pizza in the sun on a hot day.
steps.description: If it's nice and sunny, you may have better luck keeping it warm with the sun. For instance, put it on the dashboard if there's room, and the heat coming through the window will help keep it warm. If it won't fit on your dashboard, find the sunniest spot in your car.

methods.name: Encouraging the Pizza to Stay Warm at Home

steps.headline: Wrap the pizza in foil and place it in the oven on the lowest setting.
steps.description: Your oven may go down to somewhere between 170 and 200 °F (77 and 93 °C). Put it as low as it will go and wrap the pizza completely in foil, sectioning it off as needed. Set it on a pan and place it in the oven. This will keep your pizza warm for at least an hour, but keep in mind, it can dry it out a little.

steps.headline: Leave the pizza in the insulated bag with a heating pad.
steps.description: If you brought the pizza home in an insulated bag, this may be your best bet for keeping it warm. Stick a heating pad underneath the pizza and turn it to hot. This won't keep it as warm as long as the oven; it may last 30 minutes or so.

steps.headline: Create a hot cooler to keep your pizza warm.
steps.description: Heat bricks wrapped in foil in the oven at 300 °F (149 °C) for 20 minutes or use hot water bottles. Place these in the bottom of a cooler, then add a clean towel. Place the box in the cooler and close it. If the box won't fit in the cooler and stay level, wrap the pizza by section in foil and set it in the cooler that way. This may keep your pizza warm for 45 minutes to an hour.

steps.headline: Heat the pizza slowly in the oven for a soft crust.
steps.description: Put the pizza on a pizza pan and cover the whole thing with foil. Set an oven rack on the lowest shelf in the oven and put the pan on the rack. Heat the oven to 275 °F (135 °C). Take the pizza out after 25 minutes. This slow reheating process will help keep the crust soft and re-melt the cheese.

steps.headline: Aim for quick, high heat in the oven for a crisp crust.
steps.description: Set the oven to 450 °F (232 °C). Cover a pan with foil and put the pizza on top. Once the oven has heated up, place the pan in the oven for 10-15 minutes, until the cheese is bubbling. This works best for thin-crust pizzas.

steps.headline: Put slices in a skillet for a quick way to reheat pizza.
steps.description: Place a skillet (not non-stick) on the stove over high heat. Once it's hot, put the slice in the pan with the crust side down, lowering the heat to medium-high. Let it cook for a few minutes until it's warmed through and the cheese is melted. Use a lid if you're having trouble getting the cheese to melt.

steps.headline: Add a mug of water to the microwave when reheating pizza slices.
steps.description: If you don't want to wait for the stove or oven, you can reheat pizza in the microwave. The key is to set a mug of water on the plate with the pizza or to the side if there's room in the microwave. Then, heat for 2-3 minutes until the cheese is melted. The extra steam will help hydrate the pizza so it doesn't end up dry and inedible.
